YANG DI-PERTUAN NEGARA'S
SPEECH
Debate on the Address
(Third Day)


2.37 p.m.

    Order read for resuming adjourned debate on Question [14th December, 1965],

    `That the following Address in reply to the speech of the Yang di-Pertuan Negara be agreed to:-

    "We, the Legislative Assembly of Singapore, express our thanks to the Yang di-Pertuan Negara for the speech which he delivered on behalf of the Government at the opening of the present Session of this Assembly.".'. - [The Prime Minister].

    Question again proposed.

Column: 203



    Mr Speaker: At the close of yesterday's sitting. the Minister for Labour was holding the House. He now has the Floor. Mr Jek.

2.39 p.m.

    Mr Jek Yeun Thong: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Deputy Prime Minister of Malaysia has suggested that Singapore should go its own way and should not interfere with the affairs of Malaysia. This we will gladly do if they would also keep to their own word. But what happened was that when our Prime Minister talked about political eunuchs in the Federal Cabinet or the Sultans and their multiplicity of wives, they immediately sent us a protest note through diplomatic channels complaining that we were interfering with their internal affairs. When we announced our intention to resume barter trade with Indonesia, they stepped in and objected to the scheme, giving the flimsiest reasons for their objection. Is this not a blatant interference with our internal affairs? They claimed that resumption of trade with Indonesia, even though on a small scale, would jeopardise the security of Malaysia. But everybody knows that their own traders are carrying on barter trade in Tawau, Pulau Ketam -

    Mr Speaker: Order. I have allowed the Minister to continue in the vein that he has because I thought that it was relevant that the House should understand the circumstances which led to the separation of Singapore from Malaysia up to the 9th of August. Events subsequent to that date which concern the Federation of Malaysia are matters which should not he touched upon by this Assembly. But if they are matters subsequent to the 9th of August which arc relevant to Singapore and which have been mentioned by the Ministers in the Federation, then those matters may he touched upon and no other. I hope I have made myself quite clear to the House, because I am going to be very strict about this from now on.

    The Deputy Prime Minister (Dr Toh Chin Chye): On a point of clarification, Mr Speaker, Sir, I think the Minister mentioned in his speech just now the

Column: 204

exchanges of diplomatic notes between Kuala Lumpur and Singapore. He was referring to this exchange and the circumstances under which this protest was put forward. So I think it would he quite relevant if, in the process of explaining the events which took place after the 9th of August, matters which are relevant to the events are brought up in the speech. I would very much he obliged, Mr Speaker, if you could he a little generous in your interpretation of what should be debated on the Yang di-Pertuan Negara's Speech.

    Mr Speaker: Mr Deputy Prime Minister, as I have said in my ruling. I consider that any events subsequent to the 9th of August touched upon by Ministers of the Federation pertinent to Singapore may be touched upon by Members in this House. I would request Members of this House, while they are so doing, to use temperate language and not intemperate language, because if it is intemperate, I shall rule it out of order, not on the basis of subject matter but on the basis of language.

    Mr Jek Yeun Thong: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am grateful for your ruling.

    If their traders can have barter trade with the Indonesians in Malaysian territories, then why cannot we trade with Indonesia in Pulau Senang, which is 12 miles away from our main island? This, I think, is like the case of the Chinese proverb which says that high officials are allowed to set fire to a town, but the common people are not allowed even to light a lamp in their own house. If they are so concerned about the security of Malaysia and the security of Singapore, then it should he their duty to help Singapore to industrialise, because a contented people will not so easily fall into the hands of the Communists. But instead of doing this, they clamp down on trade between Singapore and the Peninsula. Every sane person knows that by denying access of their markets to our manufacturers, there can be only one consequence - the slowing down of our industrialisation programme. This would create conditions most favourable for a Communist take-over in Singapore.

Column: 205

If, as a result of their foolish measures, the people in Singapore lose hope in a democratic government and turn to the Communists, then what will be left of Malaysia's security and defence? Everyone knows that the defence of Malaysia rests on the British bases in Singapore. Can Malaysia be defended with a Communist base in Singapore?

    Finally, I would like to come to the question of the payroll tax which was also mentioned by the Member for Bras Basah. This tax was foolishly imposed by the then Federal Minister for Finance. It has the ill-effect of discouraging employers from employing more labourers that we have in surplus. When we were in Malaysia, we opposed it strongly in Parliament. But since this has already been imposed on us and since they have been collecting it for about a year, we do not intend to stop it yet. Instead, we intend to use it solely for the benefit of the workers. We intend to set aside the revenue collected under this head to form a fund for the social security of the workers. We will set up a committee to put up recommendations for the implementation of the scheme. As what we have done in all our major labour legislation and policies, the N.T.U.C. will be the first we would approach for their views and suggestions on the scheme.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to second the motion on the debate.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Deputy Prime Minister (Inche Buang Bin Omar Junid)(In Malay): Mr Speaker, Sir, I support the Address in reply to the speech of the Yang di-Pertuan Negara on the 8th of December. We are now a free and independent State and, therefore, we have to work harder to fight for the bright future of our citizens.

    All the citizens of Singapore have shown their determination to make Singapore a State that would be successful and prosperous. It is only the members and leaders of the Barisan Sosialis who hope that Singapore would face destruction so that it would be possible for them to make use of the opportunity for their own ends. That is why we see there is not a single one

Column: 206

of them present in this House. This is a clear indication that they are truly out for the destruction of the interests of Singapore.

    Singapore, as a State that believes in democratic socialism, is facing all sorts of enemies. We face threats from the Communists and the pro-Communists, as represented by the Barisan Sosialis. We are also facing intimidation from reactionary elements as represented by conservative forces in U.M.N.O., the M.C.A. and the M.I.C. Apart from that, we are also faced with intimidation from the remnants of the colonialists who carry out their evil machinations which help towards the achievement of the ends of those two forces mentioned earlier. They hope that Singapore would fail in its effort to survive, and they work hard to damage the economy of the State. These are the people who often shout out the slogan that Singapore will not survive without the cooperation of others, particularly Malaysia.

    Our State has no desire to he an enemy of anyone, particularly of our neighbour, Malaysia. In fact, the desire of the Government of Singapore is to maintain co-operation with them, particularly in the economic and commercial fields. But a matter which must be duly considered is that if economic co-operation is to be maintained with Malaysia, we do not wish any Party, particularly the conservative reactionaries of the Right, to imagine that, without co-operation with Malaysia, Singapore will fall. Singapore can survive on its own.

    Mr Speaker, we have often heard U.M.N.O. leaders in Singapore saying that for Singapore to be an industrialised State, it must depend upon raw materials from Malaya. What they mean to say is, how is Singapore to become an industrialised State without raw materials such as tin, rubber and other raw materials? I wish to say to them that for us to industrialise, raw materials are not important. Take, for instance, Japan. It does not have iron ore or rubber. Nevertheless, it is highly industrialised and produces motor-cars and other manufactured goods for their people, and these goods are exported to the

Column: 207

people of Malaysia. Malaysia, on the other hand, which has raw materials such as rubber and tin, is not producing motor-cars and exporting them. It is not industrialising. A Singapore without raw materials need not necessarily mean that it cannot industrialise. On the other hand, although a country has raw materials, it is not necessarily an industrialised country. So all the talk that to he an industrialised State, the State must have raw materials, is not exactly true.

    Singapore will prosper with its industrialisation. Daily we see industrialists from foreign countries coming here to observe what is going on in Jurong. Our people have been going to Japan and industrialists from Japan have all said that our economy is stable and they are keen to come and build factories here.

    Our country will prosper. I call upon all the citizens of Singapore to unite solidly behind the Government, to work hard and be realistic in their attitude. By the will of God, we will succeed. The Government of Singapore will defend the rights of the people, irrespective of race, language or religion. It will defend the welfare and interests of the various races of Singapore. All these things will be written in the new Constitution of Singapore.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, the Malays in Singapore need not fear that the P.A.P. Government will not look after their interests and welfare. The Government is grateful for the confidence that they have placed in it in the last general elections. The fact that the Malays in Singapore voted for members of the P.A.P. is an indication that they have full confidence in the P.A.P. Government. We will not betray their confidence placed in us. We will defend and protect the interests and welfare of them all. In the multi-racial society of Singapore, the Malays have a part to play. Let us all, irrespective of race, work hard to make Singapore a prosperous and happy country. The P.A.P. Government is working hard in order to bring about a society which is happy and harmonious because it is by this means that our people will be able

Column: 208

to live happily and in peace. That is the reason why, while we were in Malaysia, we fought for such a society through the call for a Malaysian Malaysia. But because of that, we were evicted from Malaysia. We must never forget the two years that we were in Malaysia, and we believe that they in Malaysia will not forget that too.

    The boycott of the Barisan Sosialis of this House clearly shows that they have denied their belief in democracy, and that all their fight in the past has shown that they do not care for the future of the country. Their absence from this House shows that they have no belief and no confidence whatever in the system of democracy and they are working very hard to destroy it. The people of Singapore must be well aware of these actions of the Barisan Sosialis, because the Barisan Sosialis are working very hard to destroy this democratic system. We know that they have now been rejected by the people of Singapore and so are all their pro-Communist supporters. They, like U.M.N.O. and the M.C.A., have no political capital that they could show to the people of Singapore. Mr Speaker, the Barisan Sosialis is a Party known for its skill in shouting slogans, but they are barren in political ideas. The slogans are all empty ones. In the Hong Lim by-election five months ago, the people of that constituency rejected those slogans. The Barisan Sosialis people are now rejected both by their former supporters and the people of this State. We know of the split that has taken place within the ranks of the Barisan Sosialis. They have all along been dependent for their inspiration on the Communists of Indonesia. They are now like chickens. They are now in the process of perishing. They are looking for help from outside in order to maintain their stand. They say that Malaysia is a neo-colonialist plot. They had wished earlier that Singapore would not have merged with Malaysia. Now that Singapore is no longer merged with Malaysia, this still does not seem to fulfi1 their desires. They say that the independence that we have achieved is phoney. What then are their true wishes? Merger is phoney and independence is phoney! What they wish is to destroy

Column: 209

Singapore so that it will perish. This is their evil intention towards Singapore. We must beware of this all the tune and stop the evil intent of the Barisan Sosialis.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health (Mr Sia Kah Hui): Mr Speaker, Sir, I rise to support the motion of the Prime Minister expressing the thanks of this House to the Yang di-Pertuan Negara for delivering the speech on the opening day of this Session. The whole speech conveys a sense of confidence both in the present and in the future, and the concrete and effective steps to be taken in the solution of problems which confront the country.

    As it is now well known and in fact accepted by all our fellow member nations of the United Nations Organisation but disputed by a few Barisan Sosialis Members who spit in the face of their own electors, Singapore is an independent and sovereign country. So we meet today under very different circumstances from the past. We meet as the First Parliament of an independent and sovereign Republic of Singapore. I am proud of the fact; Honourable Members here present are proud of the fact; and I am sure the great majority of our fellow-citizens of Singapore share our pride in the fact.

    At the beginning of the last Session, 21 guns did not boom out in salute when His Excellency the Yang di-Pertuan Negara arrived at this Chamber to deliver his Speech, but eight days ago, they boomed in recognition of our President. Things have changed - changed dramatically. We are now masters of our own destiny. We did not seek this status. We did not separate from those we still feel are members of our common Malaysian family. We were separated from them. This we accept. But we are an adult member of the family and can - and will - survive on our own. We live in our own houses but also in the Malaysian compound, not from any decisions of men, but because of the compulsions of history, geography and sociology. And for our own homeland, we have full and final responsibility. Our problems are not easy and we have not all the time in the world to solve

Column: 210

them. But as the Prime Minister said, we define our problems, the better to face them, and we face our problems, in order to find better and quicker solutions. We know that, though we must take the initiative and responsibility, we need the co-operation of others, our new neighbours, our Afro-Asian friends, our fellow members of the Commonwealth, the new friends made by our three Ministers on their recent journey of goodwill and the people of the American continent - in fact, wherever friendship is. But for the first time, it is our opportunity and responsibility to strive for the greatest advantage for our people. We are on test as a people and this is the greatest test we have ever faced in the success story of our history. And this time it is a democratic test - a test of all of us, of our capacity to hold together and to work together in the spirit of a more just and equal society, more equal not only in what we get from Singapore but in what we give to it. I am glad that His Excellency has fully brought Out this point clearly in his Speech. What he has said could bear repetition here, for our people must fully realise their responsibilities. I quote "Our survival as a people, depends upon our patience and resolution... upon our perseverance." In other words, these are the qualities needed to bring about a tolerant, just and equal society, multi-racial, multi-lingual and multi-religious. We have set our sights high. The ideas and aspirations may not be new, but we are pioneers in seeking to build them into the laws and way of life of one of the most varied communities in the world today. Every effort of every citizen must be deliberately directed to achieve these ideals we have set ourselves.

    If we cast our eyes around us and take an objective look at our neighbours, their trials and tribulations, we can be certain that our policy is right. Our leaders have done everything for the realisation of this policy. We have learnt from history. We know that a tolerant, just and equal society, multi-racial, multi-lingual and multi-religious, are the four pillars of wisdom on which our nation can be built. When we all fully realise this fact, and as a great majority already do, we shall

Column: 211

have peace and harmony. Without peace and harmony in our country, we cannot proceed to the next stage seeking prosperity. After the experience of the last couple of years, I am confident that our people cannot fall prey to appeals of chauvinist and communal sentiments, but at the same time we must not belittle the craftiness and ingenuity and self-mesrnerising of our enemies. They are in our midst and they are constantly and obsessively on the lookout for opportunities to exploit for the advancement of their own power through their ideology. They are constantly on the lookout for opportunities to exploit the ignorant and ill-informed. I am confident, however, that no amount of communal terror and intimidation will ever bring our people to forsake the conviction that a tolerant, just and equal society, multi-racial, multi-lingual and multi-religious, are the four pillars on which our nation shall he built. The means they use to gain power indicate the means they will use should they gain power to perpetuate their power, and there could he no greater contrast with the ideals our Government preaches and practises. As His Excellency has well said, "This House has gone through many a struggle, first against Colonialism, then Communism and then Communalism." Our people in their public as well as in their business and private life are much more experienced and discerning people. We are no fools. It is because of this very fact that our people have a discriminatory mind and have guts, patience and determination that other nations accept us and respect us. I remember that when the Deputy Prime Minister spoke at the Airport on his return from the success of his recent Goodwill Mission overseas, he said that it was because our people are solidly behind our nation's leaders that other people arc prepared to be friends with us and respect us.

    We are a peace-loving people and it cannot be said too often that we want to live in peace with our neighbours and indeed with the rest of the world. We want to prosper, and from our ideals

Column: 212

and our interests we want our neighbours also to prosper. Let this be proclaimed from the roof-tops that it may be known to our neighbours as t was stated by our Foreign Minister in his key speech to the United Nations Assembly. Let us co-operate in all things for the benefit of our peoples, which is the purpose of politics. Let not our minds and thoughts be clouded and shrunk by jealousy and animosity. The interests of the peoples must come first. This is democracy. I sincerely hope that nothing, no ideology, no people, will stand in the way as this Government strides forward to bring peace and prosperity to our people.

3.13 p.m.

    The Minister for Culture and Social Affairs (Inche Othman Bin Wok): Mr Speaker, Sir, at the opening of the First Session of the Singapore Parliament, exactly four months after the promulgation of Singapore as an independent and sovereign State, the Head of State, His Excellency the Yang di-Pertuan Negara, remarked that:

    `When we last met in this Chamber, little did we foresee that in two years we would meet here again as a sovereign Legislature of an independent nation, a separate member of the Commonwealth and of the United Nations.'

    In fact, even in this very House, Mr Speaker, Sir, the atmosphere and the scene have changed. The seats in front of us, which were 90 per cent empty after the last general election in 1963, are now all completely unoccupied. And since last Monday we have missed the sight of eight tiny men in black trousers and white shirts, shuffling in and out of this Chamber shouting silly and sometimes insolent remarks whenever Government Members spoke.

    Although we are in no position to predict the length of their absence, there are indications that their boycott will go on at least for the whole of this Session. It is hard for us to understand what sort of people they are and what they really want. They talk of democracy, but when they are given the opportunities through the democratic parliamentary process to air their grievances face to face with us, they prefer to absent themselves, to

Column: 213

shout morbid and empty slogans outside this Chamber to the effect that the Government is undemocratic and dictatorial.

    Since the 9th of August, the Barisan Sosialis has lost much of its ground support, not because of the so-called undemocratic and dictatorial attitude of the P.A.P. Government, but because of their puerile and stupid actions and utterances which are prejudicial to the interests of the people.

    At a time when we were working feverishly for the reunification of Singapore and Malaya in the establishment of Malaysia a few years ago, they worked in the opposite direction. They branded Malaysia as a neo-colonialist plot. They opposed merger to fight for an independent Singapore. Independence first, followed by merger at a later stage was their formula. And now that Singapore is no longer part of Malaysia but has become an independent and sovereign State, they say, "We do not want an independent Singapore because it is phoney independence and is a plot of the British colonialists and imperialists working hand in glove with their stooges."

    Mr Speaker, Sir, nobody can gainsay that Singapore's independence is genuine, to substantiate which there is more than ample testimony. We were admitted into the United Nations without any hitch. No African or Asian country opposed our application for membership of the Afro-Asian Conference which unfortunately failed to hold its meeting in Algiers. In fact, the United Nations as well as the Afro-Asian Conference accepted us with open arms. If our independence were phoney, as the Barisan Sosialis claimed, surely we would have been rebuffed by these two bodies.

    There is further proof of our State's legitimacy. And again, Mr Speaker, Sir, our mission led by the Deputy Prime Minister was well received and highly honoured by African, European and Asian countries. The countries they visited represented every shade of ideology from non-Communist to Communist countries. They not only accepted Singapore as an independent and sovereign

Column: 214

State but also saw the presence of the British base in the correct perspective. They were convinced that the protective base here would not negate or detract from our independence.

    Against this background we can clearly understand that at this sitting, Members of the Barisan Sosialis have absented themselves because their attempts to hoodwink the people on the phoney independence myth have failed miserably. Their unfounded allegations that independence has loaded Singapore with acute and chaotic economic problems fall on deaf ears. The people of Singapore refuse to listen to such silly and childish remarks and will not allow themselves to follow a suicidal course like that of 1961 when the Barisan Sosialis created economic paralysis by launching strikes which resulted in the closure of many factories, unemployment among workers and transfer of capital across the Causeway.

So I would first like to state that when we come to talk about the foreign policy of a country, there are two senses in which we can do so. We can identify its foreign policy by the statements of principles and objectives propounded by the leaders of a country. These are generally very reassuring and infused with high moral purposes, but these do not necessarily constitute the foreign policy of the country involved.

    Then there is another sense in which we can talk of a foreign policy, in that we can abstract it from the concrete decisions and actions taken by a country on specific international issues. From these we can abstract what the country's foreign policy is. In other words, there is a foreign policy of words, of principles, and there is a foreign policy of deeds. For practical purposes, the foreign policy of deeds is a more reliable guide to the intentions of a country than its declared and invariably reassuring principles. I am not saying that the enunciated foreign policy principles of a country are irrelevant or that they do not have any bearing on its foreign policy. They can and very often do. They denote what a country would like to do, though in the world of hard realities it may be forced to do things which do not quite harmonise with its proclaimed principles.

    It is therefore necessary for Singapore, which is venturing for the first time into the jungle of international politics, to bear in mind always these two kinds of foreign policy. We should be on the look-out for possible discrepancies between deeds and words in the foreign policy of a country. Only then can we devise our own foreign policy which is sound and realistic. For example, we should not be lulled into a false sense of security just because a country professes undying friendship and high regard for us or proclaims peace and goodwill to all men. We should satisfy ourselves first that these proclamations accord with what it does.

    Similarly, the fact that a country does not like us as a matter of principle (maybe because they do not approve of the system of government we have, or because they do not approve some of the actions that we have chosen to do), this should not preclude normal relations between us and them. Of course, it would be better if they say friendly things about us even as they enter into peaceful and workable relations with us. So in shaping our foreign policy we should have a clear idea of which category a country comes under, for upon this will depend the measure of friendship and closeness with it. While, generally speaking, we are sincere in our wish to be friendly with all countries which want to be friends with us, in the hard world of international realities there are bound to he degrees of friendship between countries.
